title: David's Royal Genealogy
shortSummary: 1 Chronicles chapter 3 details the genealogy of King David, listing his sons born in Hebron and Jerusalem, and tracing the royal lineage through Solomon down to the post-exilic period. This chapter emphasizes the fulfillment of God's covenant promises through David's descendants and the continuity of the Davidic line despite exile and hardship.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David and subsequent kings of Judah through the Babylonian exile and return

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The second king of Israel whose sons and descendants are listed, highlighting his role as the founder of the royal line.

keyCharacters.name: Solomon
keyCharacters.description: David's son and successor, known for wisdom and building the temple; his descendants continue the royal line.

keyCharacters.name: Jeconiah
keyCharacters.description: A descendant of Solomon and king during the Babylonian exile, marking a critical point in Judah's history.

keyCharacters.name: Zerubbabel
keyCharacters.description: A post-exilic leader descended from Jeconiah, instrumental in leading the people back to Jerusalem and rebuilding the temple.

definitions.definition: A significant city in Judah where David reigned for seven and a half years before becoming king over all Israel.
Women who lived with a man but had lower status than his wives; their children are distinguished from those of wives.
The period after the Babylonian exile when the Jewish people returned to Jerusalem and rebuilt the temple.
A record or account of the ancestry and descendants of a person or family, important for establishing identity and inheritance.

outline.heading: David's Sons Born in Hebron
outline.description: Lists David’s six sons born during his reign in Hebron, establishing the early part of his family and reign.

outline.heading: David's Sons Born in Jerusalem
outline.description: Details the sons born to David in Jerusalem, including Solomon, highlighting the expansion of his family and royal line.

outline.heading: Solomon's Descendants
outline.description: Traces Solomon’s lineage through successive kings of Judah, emphasizing the continuation of David’s royal covenant.

outline.heading: Jeconiah’s Descendants and Post-Exilic Line
outline.description: Records the descendants of Jeconiah, including Zerubbabel, connecting the royal line through the exile and return.

application: Trust in God's sovereign plan as seen in the preservation of David’s lineage despite trials and exile.
Value the importance of faithfulness in family and legacy, seeking to honor God in our own family lines.
Recognize God's faithfulness to His promises and covenant, encouraging steadfastness in obedience.
Commit to prayer for leaders and the continuation of godly influence through generations.

keyVerses.text: These six were born unto him in Hebron; and there he reigned seven years and six months: and in Jerusalem he reigned thirty and three years.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the two significant phases of David’s reign, marking the foundation of his kingdom.

keyVerses.text: And Solomon's son was Rehoboam, Abia his son, Asa his son, Jehoshaphat his son,
keyVerses.significance: Introduces the royal succession from Solomon, underscoring the continuation of David’s covenant line.

keyVerses.text: And the sons of Jeconiah; Assir, Salathiel his son,
keyVerses.significance: Marks the lineage during the exile period, showing God’s preservation of the royal line through difficult times.

keyVerses.text: And the sons of Pedaiah were, Zerubbabel, and Shimei: and the sons of Zerubbabel; Meshullam, and Hananiah, and Shelomith their sister:
keyVerses.significance: Zerubbabel’s inclusion points to the hope and restoration after exile, fulfilling God’s promises to His people.
